dialogue.text: Hello, how are you feeling today?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: The season has me down. No family around.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that. Are you finding time to do things you enjoy by yourself? Any hobbies?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: trying to work and write but lack motivation
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It sounds like you are feeling some lethargy in this cold season, and feel as though you have no support from your family.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I don't talk to anyone
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Do you have any plans to spend Christmas with family or friends? That may help to break the cycle of feeling low?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I live in a hotel currently No family or friends around, especially with the virus
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: What do you do for work? Are you able to get out of the hotel frequently?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I am a writer. Witht he virus it is hard to meet anyone i am only here until next week then I have to go to Virignia My children r all over the country
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I agree, it is hard to spend time with people at the moment. We are all finding ourselves spending a lot more time alone than we are used to. Perhaps you could all plan an event for next year when we will hopefully be less restricted. It would be good to have something positive to look forward to.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I try the dating sites, but they seem to far away or impersonal Hope things are better. Just the current season ahs me down
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Yes, I can see that. Keep in touch with your family and try to think of positive, happy times you can all have together in the future.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: No verbal communication makes it hard
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Can you call them?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I try but the loneliness is the hard part
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: I try but the loneliness is the hard part

dialogue.text: I am having a very anxious day today
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Hello! I am here to help, could you please tell me what the issue is?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: My mother in law is sick with COVID and my husband, when he contracted COVID from her, got terminated from his job.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I can see why you feel anxious, I would be too given the situation. When did your mother in law got sick with COVID?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yeah, it's just really stressful and I am over anxious about it. Right before Thanksgiving, she is elderly and has cancer, she is finally feeling better though.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Cancer is already a hard enough disease to fight against. My aunt is a cancer survivor. I am sure your mother can make it too.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: She is a fighter.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: From my knowledge, people usually recover from COVID after 2 to 3 weeks, you might consider having a doctor see your mother if she is still struggling.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yeah, she went again the other day. She is doing quite a bit better. He said because of underlying conditions it may take her longer, but she is doing great. That was encouraging.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: There are substantially more people recovering from covid each day despite the number of infected growing exponentially. I am sure that, with the proper care, your mother in law will make it, and so will your husband. I am sure he will be able to find a new job soon as new business start to open, even if it's a temporary one.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yeah, I guess you're right. I know you're right. I just haven't felt really in the Christmas spirit this year and I am anxious about everything I can't control. He did have an interview today too, so that is good news.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Those are some great news indeed. I am sure he will get a call soon : )
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Lol - you made me smile. Thanks. I will believe that too.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I am glad I can make your day just a little better, that's what we are here for ^_^
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: It really did help. Just talking and saying it out loud (or online) helped. Feeling heard helped.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: And I am glad you are someone easy to talk to! Some of my patients do not argument at all and expect me to end the conversation when I, as a therapist, have to make sure they are good to go! Helping you has been a pleasure!
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I am thankful for your listening to me. It does make a big difference. I am in a better mood. Thank you!

dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: The pandemic can definetely be a key factor here. When it first started, I remember feeling lost and unsure about things that I would normally would have no problem with. If you don't mind me asking, how old are you?

dialogue.text: I am 30
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Do you have any family, girlfriend, boyfriend, children?

dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Not seeing your closed ones or simply being apart from them can be more than enough to make us feel depressed or blue. Have you tried doing videocalls with them, for example?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes sometimes. I don't tell them how I feel though. I don't want them to worry about me.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I understand. However, there is nothing wrong with telling them that you are sad because you miss them. Something as simple as getting it off your chest can already make you feel better.

dialogue.text: I suppose. I just worry that I will make them sad too. It's hard time for everyone.

dialogue.text: Hello I am here to talk about my overall daily stresses
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Hello I am here to talk about my overall daily stresses

dialogue.text: Hi
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Hi

dialogue.text: Hi
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: hello. How are you?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I'm honestly having a rough time
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear that. Could you tell me about it?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Sure. I just lost my job and school is out so I feel like I have lost purpose
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Thank you for telling me. I'm sorry to hear that. What did you do for your job?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I was a manager of a retail store that closed.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I see. That's a very important role for any business. I bet there are numerous other retailers out there looking for a good manager to hire.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That is true, I am just not sure if that is what I want to do anymore
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I see. Well then, if this helps. The store closing might have been a positive thing, so you could find your next passion.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That is a good point.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I will also add, that being a Manager means you have some very important skills that would translate well to your next job, or anything you decide to do.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That's true. I know the experience will help me but I still miss it
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Also, let's say you decided to work for another company, something new, outside of retail. Because you were a manager, you could also be promoted more quickly because of your management experience.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That is also true. I guess I just need to decide what I want to do now. That is probably the most difficult part.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Yes, it sounds like a part of you still misses the retail environment. I see that too. My best advice, is take a few days to think about what you really want to do. Think about what you are skilled at. Then decide which route you want to go. I know there will be numerous options out there for you in retail management, but if you wanted to do something different, there will be opportunities there too. Because you have options, you will likely pick the choice that will be most fulfilling for you, in something you will be passionate about - so this will likely be very positive for you.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That is really nice to say. I guess I am also just scared to go for something and have it not be as fulfilling as I thought
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: That is really nice to say. I guess I am also just scared to go for something and have it not be as fulfilling as I thought

dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Yes, I tested positive for the Covid virus on Wednesday.

dialogue.text: Hello, I am feeling very sad because I tested positive for Covid this week. I am in quarantine away from my family.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: sorry to hear about that. So your test results were positive. Did I get it right?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes, I tested positive for the Covid virus on Wednesday.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It must be hard to stay alone. Are you having fever or any other sever symptoms. Hope there is someone to take care of you for a while at least.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I'm by myself in my house. My wife took the kids to stay with her father until my quarantine period is over. I have mainly cold symptoms - body aches, stuffy head, sore throat. Nothing too serious so far.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I had COVID last month with mild symptoms. Good to know that you don't have any sever symptoms. You will recover fast.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I hope so. I'm on the older side (not senior citizen yet) with high blood pressure, so I'm a little nervous about how it will affect me.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I can understand staying alone will be devastating. Keep monitoring your oxygen level. If that is normal, you don't have to worry. You can read watch tv or can do video calling to your family.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thanks for the advice. We're doing a lot of video calls so I can see everyone. That helps.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I wish for your fast recovery. Hope this COVID situation end soon somehow.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That's what is so frustrating - I feel like a couple more months or so and I'd have the vaccine. Made it a year, then get infected during the stretch run of this pandemic.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Very true! It is kind of never ending. There should be some permanent solution for it.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I don't know if that will ever happen, but if it becomes rare and much less deadly like colds and flu, we should be able to return to a pre-covid life or close to it.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: We can still hope for the best right now. Let's stay positive and fight it.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I was fighting it, but Covid won this week!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: I was fighting it, but Covid won this week!

dialogue.text: I'm not feeling great. I applied for a job recently which took a lot of time. I now have an interview and it's in 3 days. I'm getting really nervous about this because I think I need longer to prepare.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I know how you feel, I have often felt anxiety before a job interview. What makes you feel that you are unprepared?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: The thing is I'm really good at interviews but usually it takes time to prepare. It's a corporate interview so I need to prepare behavioural answers to certain scenarios. In the past this has taken me a week to learn and record to memory
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Is it possible that you could get a friend or family member to work with you on your responses? That could possibly speed up your preparation time.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes perhaps. I need to draw on previous experience so I think I'll need to prepare. I'm just so busy at work these days I just don;t think I'll have the time.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I can see that you are feeling a large amount of stress about the situation. Would it be possible to take one or more days off from work to give yourself more time?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes this is very stressful. Have you ever had a similar experience and if so how did you handle it? Potentially but this is very short notice, usually I have to provide more notice for leave from work.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Yes, I have had to deal with time pressures quite a few times. I am sure most people have in the modern era where everything moves so fast. I have usually gotten help from friends, or done my best to delay or remove other commitments from my life. As a last resort, I have sometimes had to accept that I would be getting less sleep than usual for a few days. Are there any other commitments that you can possibly delay or remove from your life while you prepare for your job interview?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Perhaps I can ask if I can finish early from work for the next couple of days and get some time that way. I do think however I'll be more nervous due to less time to prepare. The thing is I'd delay the interview but this might affect my chances. I suppose I could ask my partner to look after the childcare for the next couple of days.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: That seems like a good idea, unless that will be likely to cause you other problems. You seem like a hard working, diligent type of person that can make this work if you make the effort.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Tanks , I think I need to stay positive about this. Not sure how to handle my interview nerves however?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Well, everyone handles stressful situations differently, but there are some things you can do or try that might help. If you prepare as much as possible in the time that you have, you can be confident that you have done your best, and that is all that matters. You can decide that while you would like to get this new job, the world will not end if you don't get it, and you will worry less and have less stress. Also there is the classic technique of picturing your interviewer in their underwear. It makes them seem less imposing, and you can feel more confident. Do you think any of these ideas might help?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: There are actually some great suggestions there. The naked idea is a classic and it did make me smile. I think I am aiming for perfection when I think I should try and relax and just give it my best shot. That does help actually!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: There are actually some great suggestions there. The naked idea is a classic and it did make me smile. I think I am aiming for perfection when I think I should try and relax and just give it my best shot. That does help actually!

dialogue.text: Hello, How can I help you today?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I'm scared about my future
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Can you tell me more about why you are scared for the future?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I got fired because of Covid, and I don't know how I'll be able to find a job and have an income.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It seems that Covid has had a negative effect on your employment and financial insecurity is weighing heavily on you.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes that is correct, and with the job market, how am I supposed to find a secured job.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I can understand that feeling of insecurity, and how helpless you feel. I myself have been in the position of loss of income and financial insecurity in the past, and while it was hard while I was in the valley, I was able to walk out of it with some valuable lessons.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That is true, I just have to work hard for myself. I am learning valuable lessons like the idea that companies don't care about their workers, etc. Working more on myself sounds like the better option.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It sounds like you are already identifying areas of self improvement. A person with confidence in themselves and the ability to reflect and grow are promising attributes potential employers look for.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thank you for all that you've done today, I couldn't get through it without you dude. Thank you for your time today, hearing my concerns about the future!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: You are so welcome. I know that you will succeed in your employment search as you have the skills and humility that potential employers are looking for.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I'll continue to keep on the lookout for new job opportunities, as well as improving myself for the long term. I appreciate it!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: As you continue your job search, can you think of ways that you could trim your cost of living for the short term? Returning to the basics for a time could help save you money while you take the next steps with your career. Things like planning meals ahead of time, using items you already have instead of buying new, letting go of subscriptions you don't use daily or don't deem necessary.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I could definitely reduce my spending like going out less for fast food, cutting my Netflix and Hulu subscriptions, and prepare my own meals for the next week weeks, as I try to find a new job. This would definitely help with my concerns about income and financial security.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: I could definitely reduce my spending like going out less for fast food, cutting my Netflix and Hulu subscriptions, and prepare my own meals for the next week weeks, as I try to find a new job. This would definitely help with my concerns about income and financial security.

dialogue.text: Our lifestyle seems to be all about convenience and instant gratification, I myself being guilty of wanting those as well. But I think when we strip our needs down to the basics for a while we allow ourselves to find what is really necessary, as well as what is truly important to us.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Very true, people definitely need to find their fitting for when things go wrong. Failure or bad events give us time to think about the important things in life, as well as our true needs.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: And it is important to remember that everyone goes through cycles of feast or famine, and that when you are walking through a famine you yourself are not a failure. As long as you know you are doing your best to succeed under the circumstances you have been handed, you will never truly be a failure to yourself or to others.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thank you, this has really helped me overcome my anxiety and fears of the events from the past year!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Thank you, this has really helped me overcome my anxiety and fears of the events from the past year!

dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I'm sorry to hear this. Is there something specifically bothering you?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I just feel like no one I work with really likes me or cares about me
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: You don't think people like you or care about you at work? What specifically have they done to make you think this?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I just feel like no one talks to me and if I try and talk to them they are very dismissive
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I can understand that might make you feel uncomfortable.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I feel like I go out of my way to help people and I remember their birthdays and I try and be nice to them but no one ever does the same for me
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I have been in many work situations and even social situations where I did not feel as if I fit in, I'm rather an unusual person. I had to learn to not focus so much on BEING accepted. I had to learn what God think of me (he loves me) and try to be kind to all I meet, other centered. That is, I also had to make sure I wasn't being rude or mean. I can understand how hurtful that is. Our society isn't as kind as it once was. I find very few people appreciate kindness. However, I can't get caught up in that, it's the way people are. It isn't a reflection of myself. I think it is the hardest thing to be more concerned with others than we are with ourselves, it can be lonely.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I think from now on I’m just going to focus on myself and my family, I’m not gonna out of my way to be nice to my coworkers, I’m just going to treat them as coworkers not as friends and just keep to myself
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I think you can be kind to them, but I think perhaps your expectations are that they reciprocate, and they aren't which hurts. Perhaps be kind without expecting anything in return, and know that God sees your kindness.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I always feel like you have to be a friend to have friends, but I’m tired of being the only one putting effort in and getting taken advantage of
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I also had this happen, I had no friends and at first I thought it was me, then I realized it was an opportunity for personal growth. Which wasn't easy. How do you feel they take advantage? Being ignored is one thing, having someone take advantage of you is a different story.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I just feel like they just expect me to do things for them now and when I do it, it’s no appreciated because they just know I will do it.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I understand. Yes, then they definitely are taking advantage. Have you read anything on setting boundaries and learning how to say no?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yeah, I’m working on taking care of myself more than worrying about everyone else. I think the holidays make it even harder to set the boundaries
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I had learned once that it is so important to be able to easily say no because then we are free to say yes. Because if we say yes because we CAN'T say no, then we feel resentful. So If I can freely say no to you, then i am free to say yes, if that makes sense. Although for me, it was hard to say no, but it gets easier, now it is easy. It wasn't at first.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thank you! You have been very helpful. I think that will be my goal! Start learning to say no and don’t feel guilty about it. I think I am going to lower my expectations from other people and just start treating people as they treat me!
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Thank you! You have been very helpful. I think that will be my goal! Start learning to say no and don’t feel guilty about it. I think I am going to lower my expectations from other people and just start treating people as they treat me!

dialogue.text: Hello, how are you feeling today? Is there anything you'd like to talk about?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I am sad because I lost my girlfriend of one year.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Oh I am so sorry to hear that - this is a terrible time of year to get dumped. Please know that it will get better in time!
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Why do you think it will get better?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Well, although it sounds like a cliche, time does help with healing wounds. It took me a while to get over a break up. We had been together eight years!
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That must've been hard. Is it possible to heal without finding another?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Yes I think that it is but you really do need to be kind to yourself and give it time. Do you have good friends to support you?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Many of my friends wouldn't understand as they are in long-term relationships. But yes, I've a few good friends.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: That is a blessing at least though I know it can be hard to see people in happy relationships when you are single.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: What did you do to cope in the first year of losing your partner ?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I cried a lot to be honest, especially as he was happy with someone else. But I tried to focus on my work and my hobbies. It helped.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: What sort of hobbies helped you?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Well I love to read. Do you have anything that you could do to help you relax and take your mind off things?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Well, I do love to write but sometimes the sadness just burns me out completely and I stare at the empty page.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Do you and she have any contact at all at the moment?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I tried to make peace with her and be friends but she's bitter.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Do you feel that perhaps you did not treat her as well as you could have done?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes. I think about that all the time... I could've been better but she was my first and I was foolish. I didn't appreciate her enough.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Well, you have at least learned a lesson and in the future will treat women better I think :)
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes, you have a point. Maybe this will turn out to my favor. You have to fail to succeed sometimes.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

current_text: Yes, you have a point. Maybe this will turn out to my favor. You have to fail to succeed sometimes.

dialogue.text: Hello, how are you doing?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Well, my fiance and I "sort of" broke up recently. I moved out of our place and all, but we continued to see each other at least 3X per week. And we both said we're not 100% sure that we're ok with us being done for good. - We promised to tell each other if we start dating anyone. He said he wasn't interested in dating. Three days after that conversation, I come over unexpectedly to find him making dinner for a woman I've never seen before. Turns out it was his 3rd date with her. He met her on a dating app a week before our conversation about promising to tell each other if we start dating others.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I'm so sorry that happened. Are you mostly hurt because he didn't tell you he was seeing somebody else?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: To be honest, I'd still be hurt if he told me. But now on top of that hurt, I feel disrespected... and everything I thought I knew about him is kind of crushed. We were together 6 years, and I always, ALWAYS believed he was the most honest, kind, "stand up guy" I've ever known.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: You must feel really torn up about it. I can tell that you care about your relationship.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes, that's true. The worst part is that he doesn't seem to think I have a right to be hurt. How do I even deal with someone who hurt me but doesn't care to take any responsibility whatsoever?
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Maybe he didn't intend to hurt you. Its not like he invited you over to tease you. It is true that he didn't keep his promise, and that's his fault.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: That's true. He didn't invite me over. I expected him to be at work that night. I was coming over to see our cats, which still all lived with him. I still had a key and it didn't occur to me that I could invade his privacy since I had been spending 3X a week with him, and he was fine with me using the key. The whole thing was a shock. I wouldn't have come in had I known what I'd find inside.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: That would definitely add to the distress of the situation to have a weird surprise like that. It doesn't really seem like your fault that you were there but it is unfortunate nonetheless. Have you tried talking to h im yet?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yeah. It's a long story to explain here, but at first he told me it was a first date... then he said it was a second date... then finally he said it was a third date. I had to figure out on my own that he met her through a dating app, which makes me feel extra icky because now I kind of feel like a stalker. (Don't worry, I didn't do anything illegal or immoral to figure this out at all. He left an easy breadcrumb trail for me to follow.... but it still feels gross that I felt compelled to research the situation because I could "feel" he was lying.)
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: That's ok, you have a vested interest in this person. It is natural to be interested in such things.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes. I'm not only invested in him. I have a SUPER close relationship with his two daughters. And I love those girls so much. They're 13 and 16. They were 7 and 11 when I started seeing their dad.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: There are a lot of therapists out there that might be able to help you navigate this. It's OK to get some outside help.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Considering how much time you've put in to this relationship, I can tell you have a lot of feelings about all of this.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I do. I appreciate your talking the time to listen to me. Sometimes just talking about an issue can help organize one's feelings and thoughts.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Really, it is no problem. It helps to let it out sometimes, I feel that. Make sure you take care of your own needs before starting to smooth things over.

dialogue.text: Hello, how may i help you today?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Hello: Thanks for offering to help. My friend Mark is suffering from bi-polar disorder, and despite being on medication, is spiraling out of control. His mood swings are affecting his ability to stay employed and keep friends and family from wanting to interact with him.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I am so sorry about your friend mark. I will try my best to help you today. Is your friend mark behavior affecting you?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I suspect he's not taking his medication as prescribed. He's become a sociopath, which I understand is common with people suffering from this disorder. He's unable to be empathic or sympathetic to anyone else's life.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: To confirm your friend mark, you suspect he is not taking his medicine and that is why he is acting the way he is?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Yes, it is affecting me. In sum, I'm the only one left in his corner, but I feel like he's slipping away and becoming completely dysfunctional. It's tough with privacy laws for me to even talk to his doctor to see what's going on. I did send his doctor a long email, however, so hopefully he'll make whatever adjustments need to be made. That's my suspicion, because things seem to be getting worse, quite honestly.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Have you talked to mark about his behavior and how it is affecting everyone around him? I can understand how you feeling and that you are trying to help your friend. you are a very good friend for doing that.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I have talked to him repeatedly. Each time, he assures me that he understands my concerns and that he's going to get things together. Literally, within a day or two, I hear from a mutual friend or family member that he's reverted back to doing things that are sociopathic.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Have you asked him about him taking his medication?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: I have. He tells me that he's taking it regularly (or most of the time). I challenged him on it and told him it can't be "most of the time." That's why I sent his doctor a long email, explaining things to him, to see if he can't intervene and try to straighten him out.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: ok. dealing with someone with bi-polar disorder can be really tough and challenging but it is not there fault that they are acting the way they are. They just honestly can not help it. I know you are doing everything you can to help him and to stop him from acting that way.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: You're right. Mental illness, in all of its forms, is especially challenging. Physical illness is more easy to understand, of course.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: you are right. So do not think he is doing it on purpose. Do not let it bring you down or hurt your feelings in anyway. When did this exactly start happening?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thank you. I think you understand the sadness and anxiety in feeling powerless in this situation (or mostly powerless). I have no real expertise in this area, but by contacting his doctor, maybe he can reevaluate whether the medicine and dosage needs to be changed. Funny you ask. He's a grown man - 35-years old. I've never known him to have this issue, which seems so strange to me.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: I understand a lot.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: It started about 14 months ago - at least that's when people started alerting me to strange behavior. I thought people who were bi-polar contracted the illness earlier in their life.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: How long have you known about his bi polar diorder?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Around 10 months ago is when I first found out. Since then, I've received about 5 phone calls from people expressing concern. I've visited him 3 times. Thanks for being so engaged and sympathetic. It does make me feel better just to unload anonymously on here. Thanks for carrying my burden and offering your support.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: i got you. having a mental illness is challenging and i can provide you some suggestions.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Before we end the conversation, I'd love hearing a few of those suggestions, if you don't mind.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: ok. just be there for him no matter what because you know he can not help it. Be understanding of his mental illness. i would be active in his treatment and make sure he knows to take medicine.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Thank you. You've been great. Have a nice holiday and new year! Those are two things I've tried to keep in mind and you've reinforced my instincts. Thanks again.

dialogue.text: I feel drained, honestly. I'd love to talk about my current dilemma in my friend circle.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: Can you share the dilemma you are having?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Basically. This has happened for as long as I can remember, even back when I was a little kid. Any friend i've ever had has just used me for SOME gain. Whether that be boredom, money, or an emotional support pillow. I'm so sick of it. They'll literally ignore me for months and randomly text me for money. If i respond theyll read my messages then ignore me until they need money again. Or, they'll use me to throw alllll their problems onto me and never do the same for me. In some way shape or form- every person I become friends with uses me and throws me away when theyre done. Sometimes I feel like it must be me. Maybe i',m annoying? This happens so often the common denominator is ME. But i'm friendly, im assertive, im out spoken, im kind. I don't LET people walk all over me but it seems like that;s all I attract.
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: So you feel under valued in your relationships because people tend to take advantage of you.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Pretty much. it just happens every single time. It's kind of discouraging and just makes me an angry person
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It sounds like this is really bothering you. It is good that you are talking about it though. Have you tried telling them how they make you feel?
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Some of them. The others I never even get a chance because they just ignore my existence anytime I try and reach out to talk. I've just been waiting for them to pour their problems onto me or have the nerve to ask for money. Then i'll tell them. I already know they won't respond but atleast ill say my peace
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: After you tell them how you feel do you still give them money or listen to what's going on and try to help them.
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: No. Whenever I do get to say my peace, i'll just cut contact completely. Lately i've been holding it in and just barely responding if at all. I've told one of them that i have no money and she hasn't contacted me since. But if she tries again i'll say something about the issue. I don't like feeling used. Who even has the nerve to blatantly use somebody like that? It's irritating
dialogue.speaker: seeker

dialogue.text: It's good that you let them know how you feel. By doing that, you are taking the first step in now allowing them to take advantage of you
dialogue.speaker: supporter

dialogue.text: Agreed. I just hope that one day I can meet people and form actual friendships with them
dialogue.speaker: seeker
